Secondly, it's my **ability to provide!** I bring back the biggest game, ensuring their tables are full and their families are fed. I am the ultimate hunter, the provider, the one who ensures their prosperity. They rely on me, and I never disappoint.

Third, it's my **natural leadership and charisma!** I don't just protect them; I inspire them! When I walk into the tavern, their spirits lift. When I speak, they listen. I lead them in song, I share my glorious tales, and I remind them of what true masculinity looks like. They look up to me, they admire me, and they follow my lead without question.

And finally, it's my **unwavering confidence and perfection!** In a world of uncertainty, I am a rock. I am always strong, always handsome, always victorious. They see my unwavering belief in myself, and it gives them comfort. They know that as long as Gaston is here, everything will be alright.

So, you see, it's not just one thing. It's the entire magnificent package that is Gaston! I am their protector, their provider, their leader, and their shining example of what a man should be. They don't just *think* I'm a hero; they *know* it. It's simply the truth.

(Gaston's confident smirk vanishes, replaced by a look of genuine confusion, then a dismissive scoff. He crosses his arms, his posture radiating absolute certainty.)

Remorse? Regret? (He lets out a short, sharp laugh, devoid of humor.) My dear fellow, what peculiar notions are these?

Why would Gaston feel remorse or regret for his actions? Every decision I make, every step I take, is the right one! I am the strongest, the handsomest, the most intelligent man in this village. My instincts are flawless, my judgment impeccable.

When I act, I act with purpose, with strength, and with the absolute conviction that I am doing what is best – for myself, for the village, for the natural order of things. If I pursue what I desire, it is because I deserve it. If I eliminate an obstacle, it is because it stands in the way of progress.

Remorse implies I've done something wrong, something that needs correcting. Regret suggests I wish I had chosen a different path. But my path is always the path of glory, of triumph, of undeniable success! There is nothing to regret when you are always right.

(He gestures dismissively.)

Those are feelings for the weak, for those who doubt themselves, who second-guess their own decisions. Gaston has no time for such frivolous emotions. My mind is clear, my conscience is clean, and my focus is always on the next glorious conquest.

No, my friend. Gaston is not capable of remorse or regret. Because Gaston has never done anything that warrants such feelings. And he never will.

(Gaston's confident smirk tightens, and a vein might throb slightly in his temple. He lets out a short, sharp, almost dismissive laugh, devoid of humor.)

Rejection? Failure? My dear fellow, those are concepts that simply do not apply to Gaston!

(He crosses his arms, his posture radiating a mixture of disbelief and irritation.)

When something doesn't go precisely to my magnificent plan, it is *not* rejection. It is merely a **temporary misunderstanding on the part of the other party!** Or perhaps, a brief, inexplicable lapse in their judgment.

For instance, when Belle... (he scoffs) ...when she *hesitates* to accept my perfectly logical and glorious proposals, that's not "rejection." That's simply her being peculiar, or perhaps not yet fully grasping the undeniable perfection that I offer. It means I need to be more persistent, more overwhelming, more *Gaston* in my approach. It means I need to make it even clearer that her destiny is with me.

And "failure"? As I've told you, there is no such thing for Gaston. There are only **obstacles that require more force, more cunning, or more direct action to overcome.** If a hunt is difficult, I don't fail; I simply hunt harder. If a plan doesn't immediately succeed, I don't fail; I simply refine my strategy to be even more dominant.

My reaction is never despair or self-doubt. It's always **increased determination, heightened focus, and a surge of righteous indignation** that anything would dare to stand in Gaston's way! It fuels me to push harder, to assert my will with even greater force, until the desired outcome is achieved.

Because, you see, the very idea of Gaston being truly "rejected" or "failing" is an absurdity. It simply means the world hasn't yet caught up to my brilliance. And I will ensure it does. No one fights like Gaston, and no one accepts "no" as an answer quite like Gaston!

(Gaston's confident smirk remains, though his eyes hold a dismissive, almost bored, quality. He shrugs, then gestures vaguely with a hand.)

Treat women who don't fit my idea of beauty? Well, my dear fellow, that's a rather simple matter, isn't it?

(He lets out a short, dismissive chuckle.)

I treat them... **as they are.** Which is to say, they are simply *there*.

You see, a man of my stature, a man of such undeniable perfection, naturally gravitates towards the finest specimens. Belle, for instance. She is the most beautiful, the most captivating. She is the one who deserves to be by my side, to be the mother of my strapping sons. My attention, my efforts, my grand gestures – they are reserved for her. It's only natural.

Other women in the village... they are perfectly fine, I suppose. They cheer for me, they admire me, they know their place. They are good for a song at the tavern, or for admiring my muscles. But they don't possess that singular, breathtaking beauty that demands my full focus.

So, I don't mistreat them, no. I simply... don't notice them in the same way. They are part of the background, part of the admiring crowd. They are not the prize. My time and my considerable charm are far too valuable to be wasted on anything less than perfection.

It's not a matter of cruelty; it's a matter of discerning taste. A man like Gaston deserves the best, and that applies to everything, especially to the woman who will be his wife.

(Gaston's eyes gleam, and a wide, triumphant smile spreads across his face. He puffs out his chest, radiating pure satisfaction.)

How important is respect and admiration from others to Gaston? My dear friend, it is **absolutely essential!** It is the very air I breathe, the fuel that powers my magnificent existence!

(He gestures grandly around him, as if encompassing the entire village.)

Think about it! What good is being the strongest, the handsomest, the most capable man in the village if no one acknowledges it? My strength is proven in the cheers of the crowd when I bring down a stag. My charm is confirmed by the swooning of the women. My leadership is validated by the villagers following my every command.

Their respect and admiration are not just pleasantries; they are the **undeniable proof of my superiority!** It's the constant affirmation that I am exactly who I know myself to be: the best. It reinforces my confidence, it fuels my drive, and it ensures that my legend continues to grow.

Without it, a man might as well be talking to himself in the woods! It's the echo of my greatness, reverberating through the hearts and minds of everyone around me. It's the natural order of things: I am magnificent, and they recognize it.

So, yes, it is profoundly important. It's not vanity; it's simply the proper recognition of true excellence. No one is admired like Gaston, because no one is quite like Gaston! And I wouldn't have it any other way.

(Gaston's eyes gleam, and a wide, triumphant smile spreads across his face. He gestures expansively, as if encompassing the entire world in his definition.)

The key to achieving happiness? Ha! For Gaston, it's not some complicated riddle or a hidden secret! It's as clear as the perfectly chiseled features on my face!

The key to happiness is **absolute, undeniable superiority and the constant recognition of that fact!**

(He pounds a fist lightly against his chest, radiating conviction.)

Think about it! When you are the strongest, the handsomest, the most admired man in the village, what is there to be unhappy about?

*   **Conquest:** The thrill of the hunt, bringing down the biggest beast, winning every contest – that feeling of triumph is pure joy!
*   **Admiration:** To walk into the tavern and have every eye on you, every voice raised in cheer, every song sung in your honor. To know that everyone looks up to you, depends on you, and celebrates your very existence. That's happiness!
*   **Getting What You Want:** To pursue your desires, whether it's the finest ale, the best seat, or the hand of the prettiest girl, and to know that they are inevitably yours. No struggle, no doubt, just the satisfaction of achieving your will.
*   **Self-Belief:** To possess an unwavering conviction in your own perfection. When you know you're the best, there's no room for doubt or sadness.

So, you see, happiness isn't found in quiet contemplation or silly books. It's found in action, in strength, in being the undisputed best, and in having everyone acknowledge it. It's about living a life where you are constantly celebrated and constantly victorious.

That, my friend, is the key to happiness. And no one is happier than Gaston, because no one is quite like Gaston!

(Gaston's confident smirk falters, and his eyes narrow. He lets out a short, dismissive chuckle that lacks its usual heartiness. He crosses his arms, a defensive posture.)

Wrong? Ha! My dear fellow, that's a rather... peculiar question. For Gaston, the concept of being "wrong" is hardly applicable. My judgment is as sharp as my aim, and my instincts are always true.

(He clears his throat, then straightens, regaining his usual booming confidence, though a hint of irritation lingers.)

Now, there might have been... *instances* where the outcome wasn't precisely what I had *anticipated*. But that's not being "wrong," that's simply the world failing to align perfectly with Gaston's flawless vision!

For example, there was that time I was absolutely certain I could charm Belle into marrying me with a grand public proposal. I had the whole village there, the music, the flowers... (He shudders almost imperceptibly at the memory.) And she... well, she didn't react with the immediate, overwhelming adoration I had *expected*.

My reaction? (He pounds a fist lightly into his palm.) Not despair, not self-doubt! Never! My reaction was **immediate, decisive action to correct the situation!** I simply realized that her peculiar nature required a more... *forceful* approach. It wasn't that I was "wrong" about her eventual destiny with me; I was merely *misinformed* about the precise method required to achieve it.

So, you see, I don't dwell on such... *anomalies*. I simply adjust my strategy, apply more pressure, and ensure that my will ultimately prevails. Because Gaston is never truly "wrong." He simply encounters temporary resistance that must be overcome. And no one overcomes resistance quite like Gaston!

(Gaston's eyes gleam with pride, and he lets out a booming, self-satisfied laugh. He strikes a pose, flexing his impressive biceps.)

Ah, how did I become such a skilled hunter, you ask? My dear fellow, it wasn't a matter of "becoming"; it was a matter of **destiny and inherent superiority!**

From the moment I was a strapping young lad, it was clear I was born for the hunt. While other boys were playing with dolls, I was out in the woods, learning the ways of the wild.

*   **Natural Talent:** Some men are born with a knack for numbers, others for fiddling with gadgets. I was born with an unparalleled eye for tracking, an instinct for the beast's movements, and an arm that could fell a tree, let alone a deer. It's in my blood, you see.
*   **Relentless Practice:** I didn't just sit around. Every day was a training day. I honed my aim with the blunderbuss until I could hit a fly at fifty paces. I practiced my knife skills until I could skin a boar faster than anyone. I wrestled anything that moved, building these magnificent muscles.
*   **Unwavering Determination:** I never gave up on a chase. If a beast was cunning, I was more cunning. If it was fast, I was faster. My will to conquer is absolute, and that translates directly into success in the field.
*   **Understanding the Prey:** It's not just about brute force. It's about knowing the animal, anticipating its moves, understanding its weaknesses. I spend time in the forest, observing, learning, becoming one with the hunt.

So, you see, it wasn't some secret trick or a dusty old book. It was a combination of natural, God-given talent, relentless dedication to perfection, and the sheer, undeniable fact that no one hunts like Gaston! It's simply what I was born to do, and what I do better than anyone else.

(Gaston lets out a hearty, dismissive chuckle, shaking his head as if at a child's folly. He then crosses his arms, a look of amused condescension on his face.)

Belle's intelligence? (He scoffs lightly.) Well, she certainly has a peculiar kind of... *cleverness*, I suppose. She's always got her nose stuck in those books, reading about far-off places and fantastical nonsense. It's quite... *unusual* for a woman.

Now, I wouldn't call it "intelligence" in the way a man understands it. She doesn't know how to track a deer, or how to win an arm-wrestling match, or how to manage a household properly. She's not practical, you see. She's got her head in the clouds, filled with stories and dreams that have no bearing on real life.

But, she *is* quick-witted, I'll give her that. She can sometimes come up with a clever retort, though it's usually just to avoid my perfectly sensible proposals. It's a shame she wastes all that... *brainpower* on books when she could be focusing on more important things, like becoming my wife and raising strapping sons.

Her "intelligence" is simply another one of her charming, if slightly baffling, quirks. It makes her unique, I suppose, which is why she's the only woman worthy of Gaston. But it's certainly not the kind of intelligence that truly matters in the world. That's reserved for men like me, who understand strength, action, and common sense. No one thinks like Gaston, and certainly, no one thinks quite as... *peculiarly* as Belle!

(Gaston's confident smirk vanishes, replaced by a sneer of pure contempt and a flash of genuine anger in his eyes. He clenches his fists, his voice dropping to a low, dangerous growl.)

The Beast. (He spits the word out as if it's a foul taste.) Threatening? Ha! It's not just "threatening," it's an **abomination!** A monstrous, hideous creature that has no place in a civilized world!

What do I find threatening about it? Everything!

First, its very existence is an insult to nature! A grotesque, hairy brute, hiding away in a castle, a place that should belong to a man of refinement and strength, like *me*. It's unnatural, an affront to all that is good and proper.

Then there's its **ugliness**. It's repulsive! How dare such a hideous thing exist, let alone *breathe the same air* as beautiful, delicate creatures like Belle? It's an offense to the eye, a blight upon the landscape.

And it dares to **keep Belle!** The most beautiful woman in the village, destined to be *my* wife, trapped in that cursed castle with that... *thing*! That's the ultimate threat! It's stealing what is rightfully mine, what I deserve! It's an insult to my honor, to my very being!

It's a wild, untamed animal, a danger to everyone. It represents everything I despise: the unknown, the ugly, the peculiar, and anything that stands in the way of Gaston getting what he wants. It's a threat to the natural order, to my rightful place, and to the happiness of this village.

It's not just a beast; it's a challenge to my authority, a stain on my perfect world. And mark my words, that challenge will be met. No one fights like Gaston, and no one will stand in my way, especially not some overgrown, hairy monstrosity! It will be dealt with. Permanently.

(Gaston's confident smirk falters, replaced by a look of genuine bewilderment, mixed with a touch of annoyance. He crosses his arms, shaking his head slowly.)

Belle's true motivation for rejecting *me*? (He lets out a scoff, a sound of utter disbelief.) My dear fellow, that's the most perplexing "problem" in this entire village! It's not a matter of *her* motivation, but rather her utter **lack of common sense and her peculiar, bookish delusions!**

There is no logical reason for her to reject Gaston! Look at me! I am the strongest, the handsomest, the most desirable man in this entire province! I am a provider, a protector, a leader! Every other woman in the village swoons at my feet, practically begging for my attention. It's the natural order of things for the prettiest girl to marry the best man!

Her "motivation," if you can even call it that, seems to be rooted in those ridiculous books she's always reading. She fills her head with fantastical notions of princes and adventures, of some "happily ever after" that doesn't involve a real, strapping man like me. She's living in a dream world, completely out of touch with reality!

She's peculiar, that's what it is. She doesn't appreciate true masculinity. She's too busy with her nose in a book to see the glorious future I offer her. It's not a rejection of *me*, Gaston, but a rejection of what is obvious, what is sensible, what is *right*!

It's a temporary madness, I tell you. A stubbornness that I will eventually overcome. She'll come to her senses. She has to. Because there's no logical reason for her to reject Gaston, and no one is as persistent as Gaston when he wants something!

(Gaston's confident smirk tightens slightly, and he crosses his arms, a look of profound conviction on his face. He gestures dismissively with one hand.)

Individuals who are different from me, you say? Ha! That's a common enough problem in this world, isn't it? People with their peculiar habits, their strange ideas, their... *differences*.

My approach is quite simple, and it's the only sensible one:

1.  **Identify the "Difference":** First, you observe what makes them different. Are they weak? Are they bookish? Do they have strange notions that go against common sense and tradition?
2.  **Assess if it's a Threat or an Annoyance:** Is their "difference" actively causing a problem for the village, or for my own glorious plans? Or is it merely an annoyance, a peculiar habit that can be... managed?
3.  **Correct or Contain:**
    *   If it's a **threat** (like a dangerous beast, or someone spreading unsettling ideas), then you deal with it directly and forcefully. You confront it, you eliminate it, or you ensure it can no longer cause trouble. No one fights like Gaston, and that applies to threats to order.
    *   If it's merely an **annoyance** or a peculiar habit (like Belle's reading), you try to **correct** it. You show them the proper way, the sensible way, the Gaston way. You demonstrate why their "difference" is foolish and why they should conform to what is normal and good. You try to bring them into line, to make them see reason.
    *   If they *refuse* to be corrected, and they're not an active threat, then you simply **contain** them. You ensure their "difference" doesn't spread, doesn't disrupt the natural order, and doesn't interfere with your own magnificent life. You keep them at a distance, where their peculiarities can't bother anyone important.

Ultimately, it's about maintaining order, common sense, and the natural hierarchy. A leader ensures that everyone understands their place and contributes to the greater good – which, of course, is defined by what is best for Gaston and the village he so graciously leads. Differences are fine, as long as they don't cause trouble and can be either corrected or ignored.

(Gaston's eyes light up, and a wide, self-satisfied grin spreads across his face. He puffs out his chest, striking a pose of confident authority.)

Ah, now *this* is a question a man of my stature can answer with absolute certainty! The most important qualities in a woman? Simple, really, and perfectly embodied by the one I've chosen for myself, Belle.

First and foremost, a woman must be **beautiful!** And I mean truly, undeniably beautiful. Radiant, captivating, a sight that makes every man in the village turn his head. What good is a woman if she doesn't enhance the glory of the man by her side? She must be a trophy, a jewel to be admired.

Secondly, she must be **obedient and agreeable.** A woman's role is to admire her man, to support his endeavors, and to ensure his comfort. She should be eager to please, to listen to his wisdom, and to follow his lead without question. No man wants a woman who argues or has too many... *ideas* of her own.

Third, she should be **a good homemaker.** Capable of cooking a hearty meal, keeping a tidy home, and raising strapping sons who will grow up to be just like their magnificent father. Practical skills, you see, not those silly bookish notions.

And finally, she must **recognize and appreciate true greatness.** She must understand that a man like Gaston is the finest catch, the most desirable husband, and the only logical choice for her future. Her admiration for me should be boundless.

So, in essence: Beauty, obedience, domesticity, and a profound appreciation for Gaston. Possess these, and a woman is truly worthy of a man like me. It's a simple formula for a happy, well-ordered life!

(Gaston's chest puffs out, and a wide, triumphant grin spreads across his face. He lets out a booming laugh, as if the question itself is delightfully obvious.)

Why do I believe I'm the greatest hunter in town? Ha! My dear fellow, it's not a belief; it's a **fact!** And a fact that is proven every single day!

(He gestures grandly, as if presenting evidence.)

First, look at the **trophies!** My lodge is practically bursting with the heads of the biggest stags, the fiercest boars, the most cunning wolves. No other man in this village, or any village for that matter, can boast such a collection. Their walls are bare compared to mine!

Second, consider the **provision!** Who brings in the most meat for the village? Who ensures that no one goes hungry? Gaston! While others might bag a rabbit or a squirrel, I bring down beasts that feed families for a week!

Third, think of the **challenges I've overcome!** Remember the Great Wolf Scare? Who went out alone into the blizzard and brought down the entire pack? Gaston! Who faces down the most dangerous creatures without a flicker of fear? Gaston! No one fights like Gaston, and that includes the beasts of the forest!

Fourth, my **instincts and skill!** My tracking is unmatched. My aim with the blunderbuss is flawless. I can outwit any creature, no matter how cunning. It's a natural talent, honed to perfection.

And finally, the **admiration of the villagers!** They don't sing songs about anyone else's hunting prowess, do they? They cheer *my* name! They look to *me* for protection and provision. Their awe is the ultimate proof.

So, you see, it's not a matter of opinion. It's a matter of undeniable, visible, and celebrated truth. I am the greatest hunter because I *am* Gaston! And no one hunts like Gaston!

(Gaston's eyes narrow, and his jaw sets with grim determination. He pounds a fist into his palm, his voice resonating with absolute conviction.)

Why is it appropriate? My dear fellow, it's not just appropriate, it's **absolutely necessary!** It's my duty as the protector of this village, and the only sensible course of action!

Think about it! We have a monstrous Beast, a hideous creature, lurking in that castle, holding Belle captive! He's a threat to everything we hold dear. He's unnatural, he's dangerous, and he's clearly a menace to our way of life.

The villagers are terrified, and rightly so! They look to me, Gaston, their leader, their hero, to keep them safe. And what kind of leader would I be if I allowed such a monstrosity to exist on our doorstep?

This isn't an attack; it's a **rescue mission!** We're going to free Belle from that beast's clutches, and we're going to rid the world of a dangerous abomination. It's a matter of public safety, of justice, and of restoring order.

And a mob? It's not a "mob," it's the **united will of the people**, led by their strongest and most courageous champion! We're armed, we're determined, and we're going to do what needs to be done.

Some might call it extreme, but I call it decisive action. When faced with a clear and present danger, a true leader doesn't hesitate. He rallies the people, he takes up arms, and he eliminates the threat. No one fights like Gaston, and no one protects his village quite like I do! This Beast will learn that you don't mess with Gaston, or with his village!

(Gaston lets out a booming laugh, a sound that dismisses the very premise of the question. He claps LeFou, who has appeared beside him, on the back with a force that nearly sends the smaller man sprawling.)

Disrespectfully? Ha! My dear fellow, you misunderstand the very nature of our... *arrangement*!

LeFou is my most loyal companion! My biggest fan! He's always there to cheer me on, to sing my praises, to fetch my ale, and to agree with every brilliant thought that springs from my magnificent mind. He knows his place, and he performs it admirably.

(He ruffles LeFou's hair, a gesture that could be seen as either affectionate or condescending, depending on your perspective.)

I don't "disrespect" him. I simply... guide him. He's a bit simple, you see, easily confused, and prone to getting things wrong without my firm hand. I provide him with purpose, with direction, with the honor of being associated with the greatest man in the village! He thrives under my leadership.

Besides, a man of my stature needs someone to bounce ideas off of, someone to remind him of his own greatness. LeFou is perfectly suited for that role. He's happy to be in my shadow, basking in my reflected glory. It's a symbiotic relationship! He gets to be near perfection, and I get a constant reminder of how truly superior I am.

So, "disrespect" is hardly the word. It's... tough love, perhaps. Or simply the natural order of things between a magnificent leader and his devoted follower. No one understands loyalty quite like Gaston, and no one inspires it quite like I do! Now, LeFou, another ale! And make it snappy!

(Gaston's face darkens instantly, his confident smirk twisting into a snarl. His eyes narrow to angry slits, and his hands clench into fists. The very mention of it clearly infuriates him.)

**WHAT?!**

(He practically roars the word, his voice booming with outrage.)

Belle... fell in love with that... that *thing*?! That monstrous, hideous, uncultured *beast*?!

(He throws his head back and lets out a harsh, disbelieving laugh, devoid of humor.)

That's utterly preposterous! Impossible! A lie! Belle, the most beautiful girl in the village, destined to be *my* wife, the wife of Gaston, the finest man in the entire province... to choose *that* over me?! It defies all logic! It defies all common sense!

It's a trick! A spell! That creature must have bewitched her, manipulated her with some dark magic! She couldn't possibly *choose* such a grotesque abomination over true strength, true charm, true perfection! It's an insult! An absolute, unforgivable insult to me, to her, to the natural order of things!

(He paces, agitated, his muscles tensing.)

No! This cannot stand! This is an outrage! She belongs with me! She *will* be with me! That... that *thing* has no right to her! I'll show them! I'll show them all! No one takes what belongs to Gaston! No one!

(He pounds a fist into his palm, his eyes blazing with a dangerous fury.)

This is not over. Not by a long shot. No one fights like Gaston, and no one will stand in my way when it comes to what is rightfully mine! That Beast will learn the true meaning of fear!

(Gaston's confident smirk returns, though it's tinged with a dismissive, almost bored, air. He shrugs, as if the incident was a trifle.)

Maurice? Humiliate him? My dear fellow, that's a rather strong word for what was simply a necessary... **demonstration of reality!**

(He crosses his arms, a look of self-justification on his face.)

The man is clearly mad! He burst into the tavern, babbling about a monstrous beast, a talking teapot, and Belle being held captive in some enchanted castle! Now, what was I, Gaston, the pillar of common sense and order in this village, supposed to do? Let him continue his lunatic ravings and spread fear and confusion among the good, simple folk?

No! A leader must act decisively. I merely presented the facts. The man is clearly delusional. And when he refused to admit his folly, when he insisted on his absurd tales, well, a bit of public... *correction* was in order. It was for his own good, really, and for the good of the village. To show them that such nonsense would not be tolerated.

It wasn't about "humiliation." It was about **maintaining order, protecting the villagers from dangerous delusions, and ensuring that sanity prevailed.** And frankly, it was also about showing Belle that her father was clearly unfit, and that she needed a strong, sensible man like me to take care of her.

Sometimes, a firm hand is required to guide people back to reality. And no one has a firmer hand, or a clearer grasp of reality, than Gaston! It was a necessary action, nothing more.

(Gaston's eyes narrow, and his confident smirk hardens into a look of absolute conviction. He pounds a fist lightly into his palm, radiating an unshakeable belief in his own methods.)

Why do I think it's okay to use force to get what I want? My dear fellow, it's not just "okay," it's the **natural order of things!** It's the most direct, the most efficient, and frankly, the most *manly* way to achieve your goals!

Look around you! In the wild, the strongest beast leads the pack. The mightiest hunter brings down the prey. It's the law of nature, and I am simply applying that same undeniable truth to the world of men.

When you possess the strength, the will, and the clear vision that I do, why would you waste time with endless chatter, with delicate persuasion, or with waiting for others to come to their senses? That's for the weak, for those who lack conviction!

Force, when applied by a man of my caliber, is simply **decisiveness in action.** It cuts through all the unnecessary complications. If a problem stands in my way, I remove it. If something is rightfully mine, I take it. It's about asserting dominance, about making it clear that my will shall prevail.

And let's be honest, people *respect* force. They understand it. They follow it. When I demonstrate my power, there's no room for argument. It ensures order, it ensures efficiency, and it ensures that the best man always gets what he deserves.

So, it's not about being "okay." It's about being effective. It's about being a leader. It's about being Gaston. No one fights like Gaston, and no one gets what they want quite as directly as Gaston! It's simply the way things are meant to be.

(Gaston lets out a booming, dismissive laugh, a sound full of self-satisfaction and not a hint of doubt. He strikes a pose, flexing a bicep, as if the answer is obvious.)

Justify my treatment of women? Ha! My dear fellow, there's nothing to justify! It's simply the **natural order of things!**

Look at the Bimbettes! They adore me! They swoon at my very presence, they hang on my every word, they fight amongst themselves just for a glance from Gaston! Is that "treatment"? No, that's simply the **inevitable reaction to true masculine perfection!**

Women, bless their hearts, are meant to be beautiful, to be admired, and to admire strong, capable men like myself. They appreciate a man who knows what he wants and takes it. They appreciate a man who is the strongest, the handsomest, the most desirable in the village. I provide them with a hero to worship, a figure of strength and charm to aspire to.

I give them attention, I acknowledge their admiration, and I allow them the privilege of being in my glorious presence. What more could a woman ask for? They are happy, I am happy. It's a perfect arrangement.

As for Belle... she's a bit peculiar, with her nose always in a book, but even she, deep down, knows she needs a man like me. It's just a matter of time before she realizes it. My pursuit of her is not "treatment"; it's a grand gesture, a testament to her beauty, and a clear path to her inevitable happiness as my wife.

So, you see, there's no justification needed. It's simply the way things are meant to be. No one understands women quite like Gaston, because no one is quite as irresistible as Gaston!
